member.name: T:Hbm.Api.Common.Core.Streaming.StreamingMeasurementSignal
member.summary: Decorator class for streamable measurement signals. The class encapsulates a common signal and decorates it with streaming specific functionality (like setting a the streaming unique id). Therefore signals don't need to implement any streaming specific details (except for implementing the abstract method GetUniqueSignalID in the common signal which must return the same identification string of the signal like it is used by the streaming protocol)

member.name: M:Hbm.Api.Common.Core.Streaming.StreamingMeasurementSignal.#ctor(Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.Signals.Signal)
member.summary: Creates a new instance and encapsulates the given signal. The base class constructor assigns a new (positive) unique streaming id for this signal

member.name: P:Hbm.Api.Common.Core.Streaming.StreamingMeasurementSignal.DecoratedSignal
member.summary: The encapsulated signal instance. It can be used to write the measurement results into the buffers of the signal

member.name: M:Hbm.Api.Common.Core.Streaming.StreamingMeasurementSignal.GetUniqueID
member.summary: Returns a unique string that identifies the signal among the device to which the signal belongs.
member.remarks: In case of a streamable signal, this method must return the information used by the streaming to identify the signal on the hardware module. This information should be retrieved during scan or connect. The method implementation has to throw an cref="System.InvalidOperationException">, if no unique signal id is set.
member.returns: Unique signal identification on the device
member.exception: Thrown, if it does not contain a value.

member.name: T:Hbm.Api.Common.Core.Streaming.StreamingManager
member.summary: Encapsulates the access to the HBM streaming. Internally every using a unique session ID, so multiple parallel streaming sessions are supported. The streaming uses always sample rate groups (for each device separately) for measurement. Therefore only one time signal is internally added for each sample rate group to receive all timestamps at once for all signals of the whole group. The synchronization of the signals is disabled in the streaming layer (to safe memory and time), because synchronization for multiple devices is already realized in

member.name: M:Hbm.Api.Common.Core.Streaming.StreamingManager.StreamingDllWrapper.HBM_Stream_InitSession(System.Int32)
member.summary: Initialize the streaming library. This method must be called before calling any other function from the streaming library.
member.remarks: The complete streaming library is initialized when the first session is initialized, so no global init is required.
member.returns: 0 for success, else error code

member.name: M:Hbm.Api.Common.Core.Streaming.StreamingManager.StreamingDllWrapper.HBM_Stream_ExitSession(System.Int32)
member.summary: Cleans up the streaming library for the given session. When this method is called, no other function from the streaming library will work for this session until is called again.
member.returns: 0 for success, else error code

member.name: M:Hbm.Api.Common.Core.Streaming.StreamingManager.StreamingDllWrapper.HBM_Stream_Exit
member.summary: Cleans up the whole streaming library for all existing sessions. When this method is called, no other function from the streaming library will work. until an is called again.
member.returns: 0 for success, else error code

member.name: M:Hbm.Api.Common.Core.Streaming.StreamingManager.StreamingDllWrapper.HBM_Stream_ConnectSessionDevice(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.String,Hbm.Api.Common.Core.Streaming.StreamingManager.StreamingDllWrapper.HBM_Stream_Service[],System.UIntPtr,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Asynchonous method to open a TCP/IP connection and add the device to the steaming device collection. The method HBM_Stream_GetDeviceState needs to be called (or polled) to determine, if the device has finished connecting.
member.param: Unique streaming id of the device. This id is required to identify the device with this for other streaming methods
Services for the given IP address. For streaming, the port for the daqStream protocol and the http port are required (if the device does not use the default ports).
Number of the services in the array
member.returns: 0 for success, else error code

member.param: Unique streaming id of the device. This must be the same id, used for connecting the device for streaming
member.returns: 0 for success, else error code

member.summary: Start data acquisition on all registerd signals for the specified device.
member.param: Unique streaming id of the device. This must be the same id as used for connecting the device for streaming
0 : synchronization for signals of current device only (separated for each sample rate group); 1: synchronization for all registered signals on all devices
member.returns: 0 for success, else error code

member.summary: Enables the use of sample rate groups for signals of same sample rate. This method is necessary when using digital signals, because digital signals are asynchronous signals on the module, but are treated as synchronous signals by the streaming.

Unique streaming id of the signal on the device. This must be the same id as used for registering the signal with HBM_Stream_InitDeviceGroupSignal
Array of measurement values (or timestamp values, if the signal is a time signal)
Requested number of values to be read
Real number of measurement values read from the signal. This may be less than

Creates the internal generic circular buffer. This buffer is used during the data acquisition and should be freed afterwards using
Do not use this function, unless you have to write your own driver for a not yet supported device that needs special adjustments concerning the circular buffer. This is for internal use only!
member.remarks: If you want to set the number of buffered values explicitly, set buffer timeout to 0 and min numbers of buffered values to demanded value.

member.name: T:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.Signals.CanRawSignal
member.summary:
Represents a signal delivered by a CAN Raw receiver. The measurement values of this signal are more complex and the values cannot be represented by just one double value (like for all other signal types as e.g. AnalogInSignal, etc.). In fact the measurement values of the CanRawSignal are s which are accessible in 2 ways:
New way (newly introduced - until now for CAN Raw data \only):
You can access the values by using the IGenericSignal Interface to get the \of the CanRawSignal. To access the s, which are the Values of the GenericMeasurementValues, a further cast to MeasurementValuesBase<CanRawMessage> has to be made. Following code snippet will demonstrate the access to the CanRawMessages of a CanRawSignal:
if (signal is IGenericSignal genericSignal) { if (genericSignal.GenericMeasurementValues is MeasurementValuesBase <CanRawMessage> canRawMeasurementValues) { // now you have access to // canRawMeasurementValues.UpdatedValueCount // canRawMeasurementValues.Timestamps[0..canRawMeasurementValues.UpdatedValueCount-1] // relative (to measurement start) timestamps (starting around 0.0) // canRawMeasurementValues.Values[0..canRawMeasurementValues.UpdatedValueCount-1].Timestamp // absolute! timestamp here (the one of the message itself) // canRawMeasurementValues.Values[0..canRawMeasurementValues.UpdatedValueCount-1].Header // header of the CanRawMessage // canRawMeasurementValues.Values[0..canRawMeasurementValues.UpdatedValueCount-1].Payload[0...63] // 64 Bytes Payload because of CAN FD data } }
Second way (the "normal" one, which you already use for all other signal types):
You can access the values, as you already do it for all other signals, by accessing . If you do so, you will notice that in case of a CanRawSignal, there are always a multiple of 10 [n...n+9], which do have the exact same time information and - by this - mark the corresponding [n...n+9] as belonging together, representing one CanRawMessage. When you take a look into the , you also will notice a certain pattern - also with a length \of 10 values[n...n+9]. The meaning of these 10 double values (Values[n...n+9]), which represent 1 CanRawMessage are: 1. Values[n] = absolute timestamp of the can raw message 2. Values[n+1] = header of the can raw message (coded as double! so you have to convert the 8 bytes of the double into 8 bytes of an ULong to get its real value) 3. Values[n+2] = 1. 8 byte payload (coded as double! so you have to convert the 8 bytes of the double into 8 bytes) 4. Values[n+3] = 2. 8 byte payload (coded as double! so you have to convert the 8 bytes of the double into 8 bytes) 5. ... 6. Values[n+9] = 8. 8 byte payload (coded as double! so you have to convert the 8 bytes of the double into 8 bytes) So the Values[n+2] ... Values[n+9] hold the payload of the can message which you have to convert from 8 doubles into an array of 64 bytes to get the real data. You should use this way of getting the can messages if you do not want to change the way of getting measurement values (e.g. if you already safe your measurement values and you do not want to change the way to safe them). So there are no code changes necessary to safe your CAN Raw measurement values. However - to understand your measurement data (e.g. after loaded from file again), it is necessary to convert them into CanRawMessages to understand the data.
To transform the 10 Values into 1 CanRawMessage, you can simply use the constructor of :
// suppose you have the Values (here just containing ONE CanRawMessage) available // e.g. after loading from disk or getting directly during a measurement.. int startIndexOfCanMessage = 0; //10,20,30... always a multiple of 10 because 10 "normal" measurement values represent one CanRawMessage CanRawMessage canRawMessage = new CanRawMessage(signal.ContinuousMeasurementValues.Values[startIndexOfCanMessage], signal.ContinuousMeasurementValues.Values[startIndexOfCanMessage + 1], new double[] { signal.ContinuousMeasurementValues.Values[startIndexOfCanMessage + 2], signal.ContinuousMeasurementValues.Values[startIndexOfCanMessage + 3], signal.ContinuousMeasurementValues.Values[startIndexOfCanMessage + 4], signal.ContinuousMeasurementValues.Values[startIndexOfCanMessage + 5], signal.ContinuousMeasurementValues.Values[startIndexOfCanMessage + 6], signal.ContinuousMeasurementValues.Values[startIndexOfCanMessage + 7], signal.ContinuousMeasurementValues.Values[startIndexOfCanMessage + 8], signal.ContinuousMeasurementValues.Values[startIndexOfCanMessage + 9] }); // now you can access the CanRawMessage properties // canRawMessage.Timestamp; // (double) absolute! timestamp here (the one of the message itself) // canRawMessage.Header; // (ulong) header of the CanRawMessage // canRawMessage.Payload[0...63]; // (byte[64]) 64 Bytes Payload because of CAN FD data
The CanRawMeasurementValues are of type CanRawMessage. One CanRawMessage (CanRawMeasurementValues.Value) is mapped to 10 "normal" ContinuousMeasurementValues as described above.
This is why you always get 10 "normal" ContinuousMeasurementValues for one CanRawMeasurementValue! The API cares about providing both ways to get access to CanRawMessages.
Following diagram shows the relation between GenericMeasurementValues and ContinuousMeasurementValues of the CanRawSignal:
member.remarks:
No matter how you prepare the data acquisition, CanRawSignal allocates always max. 100000 ContinuousMeasurementValues and 10000 GenericMeasurementValues of type CanRawMessage. If you run into memory problem (BufferOverFlowOccurred set to true), please request data more often by calling more frequently!
IMPORTANT: Since this is perhaps a bit hard to understand, we also provide a section within the CommonAPI Demo Project that demonstrates CAN Raw handling.

member.summary: Represents a digital signal that holds n digital compressed signals, that were all fed with the SAME measurement value. Thereby the bitmask of a digital compressed signal defines the bit of the measurement value that represents its own measurement value.

List of digital signals for one compression group

member.summary: Group to which all signals, collected under DigitalCompressedSignals, belong.

member.name: P:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.Signals.DigitalCompressedGroupSignal.DigitalCompressedSignals
member.summary: List of digital compressed signals that all use the measurement values of this signal to calculate their own measurement values. Typically one bit position of a measurement value of this signal is mapped to one measurement value of a digital compressed signal.

member.name: M:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.Signals.DigitalCompressedGroupSignal.GetUniqueID
member.summary: Returns a unique string that identifies the first signal among the list of digital compressed signals
member.remarks: In case of a streamable signal, this method must return the information used by the streaming to identify the signal on the hardware module. This information should be retrieved during scan or connect.
member.returns: Unique signal identification on the device

member.name: T:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.Signals.DigitalCompressedSignal
member.summary: A digital comressed signal is part of a DigitalCompressedGroupSignal which delivers one measurement value for n digital signals. E.g.: A device that delivers one 16 bit value for 16 digital in pins, holds 16 digital compressed input signals, each mapped on one bit of the measurement value (according to its masked bit).

member.name: P:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.Signals.DigitalCompressedSignal.Group
member.summary: Group to which this signal belongs. A group defines a logical compound of digital signals that are actually only one physical signal - e.g. a digital in port with n pins that are mapped onto one signal. Each bit of this physical signal belongs to another digital signal of the same group.

member.name: P:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.Signals.DigitalCompressedSignal.MaskedBit
member.summary: Defines the bit of the measurement value that is mapped on this digital signal. Possible values are 0 ..31

member.name: P:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.Signals.DigitalCompressedSignal.MaskedBitValue
member.summary: Returns the value that corresponds to the masked bit. (E.g.: If the MaskedBit is 3, the correspondent value is 2^(3)=8 )

member.name: M:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.Signals.DigitalCompressedSignal.DecompressMeasurementValues(Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.Signals.DigitalCompressedGroupSignal)
member.summary: Updates the ContinuousMeasurementValues of this signal according to the ContinuousMeasurementValues of the digitalCompressedGROUPSignal by calculating the measurement values for this digital compressed signal according to its masked bit value and the measurement values of the digital compressed group signal.
member.param: Signal that holds the measurement values to map (according to masked bit value) to the measurement values of this signal

member.name: M:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.Signals.Signal.FreeCircularBuffer
member.summary: Frees the internal circular buffer. After the data acquisition has been stopped this buffer is no longer needed. Do not use this function, unless you have to write your own driver for a not yet supported device that needs special adjustments concerning the circular buffer. This is for internal use only!

member.name: P:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.Values.CanRawMessage.Payload
member.summary: Payload of the message as byte[]. The size is fix set to 64 bytes, so it may contain up to 64 bytes, delivered by CAN FD. In case of standard CAN, only 8 bytes payload will be filled.

member.name: T:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.Values.MeasurementValuesCircularBufferBase`1
member.summary: Manages a circular buffer to buffer Hbm.API.Common.Entities.MeasurementValues. If values will not be fetched before buffer is full, the oldest values within the buffer will be overwritten and BufferOverflowOccurred will be set to true until values will be fetched from buffer again.

member.name: M:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.Values.MeasurementValuesCircularBufferBase`1.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Circular buffer for measurement values

member.name: P:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.Values.MeasurementValuesCircularBufferBase`1.NumberOfValuesInCircularBuffer
member.summary: Number of not yet fetched values in the buffer

member.name: P:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.Values.MeasurementValuesCircularBufferBase`1.BufferOverflowOccurred
member.summary: True, if a buffer overflow has been occurred since the last call of GetValues. (A buffer overflow happens if valuesAdded> bufferSize+valuesFetched)

member.name: P:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.Values.MeasurementValuesCircularBufferBase`1.StartTime
member.summary: Start time of measurement. If measurement has been started synchronized StartTime is the earliest timestamp of all signals (after they have been synchronized) that take part in measurement. If measurement has been started unsynchronized StartTime is 0

member.name: P:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.Values.MeasurementValuesCircularBufferBase`1.NumberOfNewValuesSinceLastAdd
member.summary: Gets the count of new values since the last data fetch.

member.name: P:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.Values.MeasurementValuesCircularBufferBase`1.IsValueAdded
member.summary: Returns true if values have been added to the circular buffer since the last time of this function. This is used to check if the signal still receives new measurement data (for detecting signal lost timeout).

member.name: M:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.Values.MeasurementValuesCircularBufferBase`1.SetStartTime(System.Double)
member.summary: Sets the start time for the timestamps. The timestamps that are already stored in the circular buffer will be decreased by this time during the execution of this function.
member.param: Time in seconds since 1.1.2000 that is subtracted from all timestamps within the circular buffer. When adding values via to the circular buffer, this start time will be subtracted from the timestamps of the values to add.

member.name: M:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.Values.MeasurementValuesCircularBufferBase`1.AddValues(`0[],System.Double[],Hbm.Api.Common.Enums.MeasurementValueState[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Adds numberOfValuesToAdd "measurement value lines" to the circular buffer
member.exception: Thrown, if numberOfValuesToAdd is less than 0.
Thrown, if size of measurementValues, timeStampValues or statusValues is less than numberOfValuesToAdd.
Thrown, if measurementValues, timeStampValues or statusValues is null.

member.name: M:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.Values.MeasurementValuesCircularBufferBase`1.GetValues(System.Int32,Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.Values.MeasurementValuesBase{`0})
member.summary: Gets the demanded number of measurement values from circular buffer
member.param: Number of measurement values to get from circular buffer
Hbm.API.Common.Entities.MeasurementValues object to copy circular buffer values to
member.remarks: Size of Hbm.API.Common.Entities.MeasurementValues will be extended, if current buffer size is to small to get all demanded values. If numberOfValuesToGet is bigger than the number of available values in the circular buffer, the number of updated values it set to number of available values!
member.exception: Thrown, if numberOfValuesToGet is less than 0.
Thrown, if measurementValues is null.

member.name: M:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.Values.MeasurementValuesCircularBufferBase`1.PeekValues(System.Int32,Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.Values.MeasurementValuesBase{`0})
member.summary: Returns the next available MeasurementValues but does not consume them. So the demanded values will not be "removed" from circular buffer!
member.param: Number of measurement values to peek
Reference to an existing MeasurementValues object
member.exception: Thrown, if numberOfValuesToPeek is less than 0.
Thrown, if measurementValues is null.

member.name: M:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.Values.MeasurementValuesCircularBufferBase`1.Reset
member.summary: Resets the circular buffer. NumberOfValuesInCircularBuffer will return 0 after calling this function. The Size of the circular buffer remains unchanged.

member.name: M:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.Values.MeasurementValuesCircularBufferBase`1.IncrementReadPointer(System.Int32)
member.summary: Increments the read pointer by the given increment (by considering "wrap around" of circular buffer) This function will be used during the execution of DaqMeasurement.StartDaq() function (due to getting same start-timestamp for all signals)

member.name: M:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.Values.MeasurementValuesCircularBufferBase`1.GetValuesFromBuffer(System.Int32,Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.Values.MeasurementValuesBase{`0})
member.summary: Gets (a prior calculated) numberOfValuesToGet new measurementValues from circular buffer
member.param: Number of measurement values to get from circular buffer
MeasurementValues object to copy circular buffer values to
member.remarks: MeasurementValues buffer size will be reallocated, if current bufferSize is to small to get all demanded values. If numberOfValuesToGet is greater than the number of available values in the circular buffer, the number of updatedValues it set to number of available values!

member.name: M:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.Values.MeasurementValuesCircularBufferBase`1.CopySuccessiveMeasurementValues(System.Int32,System.Int32,Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.Values.MeasurementValuesBase{`0},System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Copies given number of SUCCESSIVE values from internal circular buffer into a given measurementValues target, depending of the flags FirstStatusOnly and FirstTimeStampOnly.
member.param: Number of successive values to copy.
Start position of values to copy.
Target to copy the values to.
Start position within target to copy the values to.

True, if this call should copy the first part of the circular buffer to the target (BEFORE a wrap). In this case we have to copy only the first timestamp or status if IsFirstTimeStampOnlyRequested or IsFirstStatusOnlyRequested of target is true.

member.name: T:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.Values.MeasurementValuesCircularBuffer
member.summary: Manages a circular buffer to buffer Hbm.API.Common.Entities.MeasurementValues. If values will not be fetched before buffer is full, the oldest values within the buffer will be overwritten and BufferOverflowOccurred will be set to true until values will be fetched from buffer again.

member.name: T:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.DeviceStatus
member.summary: Represents one status information of a device.
member.remarks:
A subclass should at least realize a property Value (normally an enumeration type) which contains the value of the status.
Further sub classing should realize a property DeviceSpecificValue and set the base class Value = MyEnum.DeviceSpecific as an indicator (see and its subclass in the QuantumX driver).

member.name: T:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.Filters.ButterworthFirFilter
member.summary: The Butterworth FIR (Finite Impulse Response) filter is a type of signal processing filter, designed to have a frequency response as flat as possible in the band-pass. It is also referred to as a maximally flat magnitude filter.

member.summary: Converts the name and frequency of the filter into a human readable string representation, e.g. Butterworth FIR, 10 Hz
member.returns: Converted and concatenated filter string

member.name: T:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.Filters.LinearPhaseFilter
member.summary: The linear phase FIR (Finite Impulse Response) filter is a type of signal processing filter.

member.name: M:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.Filters.LinearPhaseFilter.ToString
member.summary: Converts the name and frequency of the filter into a human readable string representation, e.g. LinearPhase, 50 Hz
member.returns: Converted and concatenated filter string

member.summary: Not supported filter is used to indicate, that an unknown filter is set in the device.

member.summary: Creates new instance

member.name: M:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.Filters.NotSupportedFilter.ToString
member.summary: Converts the name and frequency of the filter into a human readable string representation
member.returns: Filter string

member.name: T:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.Filters.BesselFilter
member.summary: Bessel IIR (Infinite Impulse Response) filter is a type of linear filter with a maximally flat group delay (maximally linear phase response). They are characterized by almost constant group delay across the entire band-pass, thus preserving the wave shape of filtered signals in the band-pass.

member.name: M:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.Filters.BesselFilter.ToString
member.summary: Converts the name and frequency of the filter into a human readable string representation, e.g. Bessel, 10 Hz
member.returns: Converted and concatenated filter string

member.name: T:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.Filters.ButterworthFilter
member.summary: The Butterworth IIR (Infinite Impulse Response) filter is a type of signal processing filter, designed to have a frequency response as flat as possible in the band-pass. It is also referred to as a maximally flat magnitude filter.

member.name: M:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.Filters.ButterworthFilter.ToString
member.summary: Converts the name and frequency of the filter into a human readable string representation, e.g. Butterworth, 10 Hz
member.returns: Converted and concatenated filter string

member.name: T:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.Filters.HighpassFilter
member.summary: Filter, that passes high-frequency signals but reduces the amplitude of signals with frequencies lower than the cutoff frequency.

member.summary: Converts the name and frequency of the filter into a human readable string representation, e.g. Highpass, 5 Hz

member.name: T:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.ISkillReader
member.summary: Interface to get information about detailed parameterization options of a certain device. Implement this interface for each device family for each type of data source (textfile, database, dll, etc.) you want to support. The file DeviceDriver.plugins defines which SkillReader will be used for each device family.

Signal from which to get the possible filter frequencies (depending on its filter)
member.returns: List of possible filter frequencies

member.name: T:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.TimeSources.AutoTimeSource
member.summary: The device uses its internal synchronization method. You could use this time source e.g. when measuring a number of QuantumX devices that are connected via a FireWire cable, or when measuring a number of MGC or PMX devices using their sync cable.

member.name: T:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.TimeSources.EtherCatTimeSource
member.summary: The device uses the Ethernet for Controller and Automation Technology to synchronize with other devices. It achieves clock accuracy in the sub-microsecond range. You could use this time source e.g. when measuring various QuantumX devices, which are not connected via FireWire.

member.name: T:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.TimeSources.NotSupportedTimeSource
member.summary: Class that holds the settings for a not supported time synchronization type

member.name: T:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.TimeSources.NtpTimeSource
member.summary: The device uses the Network Time Protocol (NTP) protocol to synchronize its clock throughout a computer network against a given time server. On a local area network, it achieves clock accuracy better than one millisecond. You could use this time source e.g. when measuring a QuantumX and a PMX or a MGC device in parallel.

member.name: M:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.TimeSources.NtpTimeSource.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Creates new instance with given parameters
member.param: IP address of the NTP time server

member.name: P:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.TimeSources.NtpTimeSource.ServerIpAddress
member.summary: IP address of the NTP time server

member.name: T:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.TimeSources.PtpTimeSource
member.summary: The device uses the Precision Time Protocol (PTP) protocol to synchronize its clock throughout a computer network. On a local area network, it achieves clock accuracy in the sub-microsecond range. You could use this time source e.g. when measuring various QuantumX devices, which are not connected via FireWire.

member.name: M:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.TimeSources.PtpTimeSource.#ctor(Hbm.Api.Common.Enums.DelayMechanism,Hbm.Api.Common.Enums.TransportMode)
member.summary: Creates new instance with given parameters
member.param: PTP delay mechanism used to synchronize the device
PTP transport mode used to synchronize the device

member.summary: PTP delay mechanism used to synchronize the device

member.name: P:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.TimeSources.PtpTimeSource.TransportMode
member.summary: PTP transport mode used to synchronize the device

member.name: P:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.Device.IsReadingDaqValues
member.summary: Indicates if the device is updating its measurement values This is internally used to decide whether a new task for reading values from device is started or not. If the device is still reading DAQ values, we do not start a new task.

member.name: P:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.Device.IsUsingHbmClassicSampleRates
member.summary: Indicates if the device is using the classic HBM sample rates (e.g. 1200 Hz, 2400 Hz, 4800 Hz, ... ) instead of the decimal sample rates ( 10 Hz, 100 Hz, 1000 Hz, ...) The property is valid after the device has been connected. At present only the QuantumX device family supports decimal sample rates.

member.name: M:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.Device.GetTimeSourceQuality(System.Double@,System.String@)
member.summary: Returns the offset (timespan between synchronization time source and time of device) in ms and a dependent string with further information about the quality of the synchronization. For this string includes the parameters (comma seperated): "remote, refid, st, t, when, poll, reach, delay, offset, jitter" For this string includes the following parmeters (comma seperated): "GrandmasterID, SyncMode, TimeScaleFlags, UtcOffset, UtcOffsetUsed, MasterOffset"
member.param: Offset to time source in milliseconds, if offset can not be determined
TimeSource type dependent information about the synchronization quality.

member.name: M:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.Device.Reset(System.Collections.Generic.List{Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.Problems.Problem}@)
member.summary: Resets the device to its factory default settings. Caution! After this function has been called, the device will be disconnected. This is necessary because the parameterization of the device changes by loading the factory defaults and the device therefore will be no longer consistent with the associated object model of the device. (When implementing this function, be sure to disconnect the device and to call to signal that the device has been disconnected.)
member.param: Warnings and errors that occurred during resetting the device
member.returns: true if no error has occurred, otherwise false
member.remarks: Notice that the device may be unreachable for a certain time and the device is disconnected after the execution of this function.

member.summary: Prepares a continuous measurement session.

member.exception: Thrown if contains a signal that does not belong to this device.
Thrown if there were errors during the preparation of the measurement (e.g. not supported sample rates or to many sample rates for this device)

member.name: M:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.Device.BeginStartDaq
member.summary: Starts an already prepared (via PrepareDaq) continuous measurement session without waiting for any reply of the device. Use this function in combination with CompleteConcurrentStartDaq. This function has to return as fast as possible to be able to start as many devices as possible in a minimum of time. In a typical realization you would e.g. send the start command to your device without waiting for an answer. Use the EndStartDaq function to check the answer of the start command. This approach asserts that starting n devices does not take significantly longer than starting one device only.
member.exception: Thrown, if there was a problem during start of the data acquisition.

member.name: M:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.Device.EndStartDaq
member.summary: Ends the concurrent start of data acquisition (initiated via BeginStartDaq) Use this function to check if the data acquisition of this device could be started.
member.exception: Thrown, if there was a problem during start of the data acquisition.

member.name: M:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.Device.ReadDaqValues
member.summary: Updates the Signal.CircularBuffer of all signals that take part in the continuous measuring

member.name: M:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.Device.StopDaq
member.summary: Stops a running continuous measurement session

member.name: M:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.Device.MapConnectionInfo(Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.ConnectionInfos.ConnectionInfo)
member.summary: Maps the given ConnectionInfo to a possible ConnectionInfo for the device. If this is not possible, the function returns null. Example: Given ConnectionInfo is EthernetConnectionInfo but the device supports StreamingConnectionInfo only: The function maps the EthernetConnectionInfo onto a StreamingConnectionInfo and fills the missing parameters e.g. with default streaming parameters if possible. If this is not possible the function has to return null.
member.param: The ConnectionInfo to map onto a supported ConnectionInfo
member.returns: Valid ConnectionInfo for the device or null if mapping is not possible

member.name: M:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.Device.GetPossibleDataAcquisitionModes
member.summary: Gets the possible data acquisition modes according to the current synchronization settings of the device. When the device detects a hardware synchronization (typically established via a synchronization cable), the returned list will will contain the mode . If the device uses a time based synchronization (e.g. PTP or NTP), the returned list will contain the mode . Since most devices are able to fulfill an unsynchronized measurement, the returned list will most likely contain the mode . If the device is not connected, the list of possible data acquisition modes will be empty.
member.returns: List of possible for this device according to its current synchronization settings.

member.returns: Unique device identification or String.Empty, if identifier is not set

Use this function to setup e.g. trigger master and trigger slave, choose certain time stamp settings etc. which is relevant for the given data acquisition mode. Since all devices of a certain device family, that take part in the measurement are also given to this function, there is the possibility to handle certain devices in different ways (e.g. trigger master gets other settings/preparations than the slaves etc.).

member.summary: Subscribes the given signal references and starts also the streaming so that it is possible to call and to call until the signal references will be unsubscribed again
member.param: Signal references to get data from

member.name: M:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.StreamingDevice.ReadFlatArray(System.String,System.Double@,System.Double[]@,System.UInt32@,System.Double@)
member.summary: Reads an array of doubles from stream
member.param: Signal reference for which to get data.
Timestamp when the values were measured by the device.
Number of read elements (with a flat array the dimension is always 1 so the number of elements corresponds to the number of values).

member.name: M:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.StreamingDevice.ReadMultiDimensionalArray(System.String,System.Double@,System.UInt32@,System.Double[]@,System.UInt32@,System.Double@)
member.summary: Reads a multidimensional array from given streaming device and signal reference
member.param: Signal reference for which to get data.
Timestamp when the values were measured by the device.
Concatenated values according to the number of read dimensions
Number of read elements (for a multi dimensional array the number of values would corresponds to the number of elements + number of dimensions).

member.name: M:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.StreamingDevice.StopSpectrumRead
member.summary: Unsubscribes the signal references (and stops getting data for these signal references)
member.remarks: This function just stops collecting data for all subscribed signal references!

member.name: M:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.StreamingDevice.GetSignalReferencesViaStreaming

member.returns: List of all signal references

member.name: M:Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.StreamingDevice.FillSignalPropertiesViaStreaming
member.summary: Fills all signals of this device instance with information gathered by streaming. For now only and Unit will be filled/updated. To be able to fill the Unit, the signals have to implement the interface. Otherwise no unit will be set for the signals!

member.name: T:Hbm.Api.Common.Enums.DataAcquisitionMode
member.summary: Data acquisition mode.
member.remarks: Data Acquisition Mode defines the procedure that is used to synchronize different devices during the start of a measurement (DaqMeasurement.StartDaq) and also the way measurement values will be provided (DaqMeasurement.FillMeasurementValues).

member.name: F:Hbm.Api.Common.Enums.DataAcquisitionMode.TimestampSynchronized
member.summary: Use this mode, if the synchronization of the devices should be done by using the timestamps of the delivered measurement values. (E.g.: A compound of QuantumX devices delivers equal timestamps if they are connected via FireWire cable. A compound of PMX devices should use the same NTP server to deliver synchronized timestamps.) Equidistant and not equidistant (asynchronous) signals may be mixed. Not equidistant signals have to sent values before given timeout in DaqMeasurement.StartDaq occurs.

member.name: F:Hbm.Api.Common.Enums.DataAcquisitionMode.HardwareSynchronized
member.summary: Use HardwareSynchronized if the devices are synchronized by hardware (cable) and are able to deliver a concurrent first measurement value for all signals. (E.g.: A compound of MGC devices that are connected via sync cable and are proper configured (master/slave) deliver a concurrent first measurement value for all signals.)

member.name: F:Hbm.Api.Common.Enums.DataAcquisitionMode.Unsynchronized
member.summary: Use Un-synchronized to start a measurement without any synchronization.

member.name: F:Hbm.Api.Common.Enums.DataAcquisitionMode.Auto
member.summary: Use this mode to let the API decide which mode should be used.

member.summary: Only MX590: The pressure setting in TEDS is below the sensor specification (only sub-range of the amplifier in use).

member.name: F:Hbm.Api.Common.Enums.TedsValidationValueType.TedsValidRequestPressureAboveAmp
member.summary: Only MX590: The pressure setting in TEDS is above the sensor specification (damage to the amplifier possible).

member.name: T:Hbm.Api.Common.DaqMeasurement
member.summary:
Class that manages data acquisition.
Use this class to execute a continuous measurement. Therefore you should keep with following work flow: * Scan for devices () * Connect to device(s) () * Add/Remove signals to/from measurement (, ) * Prepare data acquisition () * Start data acquisition () * Loop * Get measurement values() * Do something with these values * Loop end * Stop data acquisition ()
After a device has been (and prepared to your measurement task - e.g. by Device.AssignConnector, you can choose signals of the device you want to measure. Each of these signals has to be added to the measurement.
Call to let the API allocate the internal circular buffers of the signals and do further internal preparations like sorting signals into different groups for different sample rates etc.
To start the measurement, you have to call . If you use more than one device and the devices are synchronized (that means that the system time on the devices is pretty equal), you should start the data acquisition with . In case of a synchronized measurement, the first timestamp of each signal will ideally be the same (or at least as close to each other as possible).
To get measurement values, the function has to be called periodically. Until the next call to this function, you can access the measurement values under \of the signals you added to the measurement. If the measurement has been started synchronized, it is guaranteed, that each signal with same sample rate (distributed to various devices) gets the same number of new measurement values.
ends a running measurement and removes all, prior added signals from the measurement. So keep in mind to add the signals again before preparing/starting a new measurement.

member.summary: Creates new instance of the class

member.summary: Creates new instance of the class
member.param: Time interval in ms, in which measurement data is requested from all devices that take part in a measurement session.

member.name: M:Hbm.Api.Common.DaqMeasurement.Finalize
member.summary: Destructor. Cleans up all things if not yet done....

member.name: P:Hbm.Api.Common.DaqMeasurement.DataFetchingInterval
member.summary: Time interval in ms, in which measurement data is requested from all devices that take part in a measurement.

member.name: P:Hbm.Api.Common.DaqMeasurement.MeasurementStartUTCTime
member.summary: Start date and time of the latest measurement in UTC format. This is the minimum timestamp of all signals that take part in a measurement. Format is UTC unix time (seconds since 1.1.2000, the post decimal places are the running second)
member.remarks: Notice, that this is NOT local time, but Greenwich Mean Time (GMT)

member.name: P:Hbm.Api.Common.DaqMeasurement.MeasurementStartTime
member.summary: Start time and date of the latest measurement. This time is generated by transforming the first timestamp of the latest measurement( into the local date time representation of this computer.
member.remarks: This is local time and date (depends on your region and summer/winter time)!

member.name: P:Hbm.Api.Common.DaqMeasurement.MeasurementStartSystemTime
member.summary: Local start time and date of the latest measurement, executed on this computer. This time is taken from the PC when calling the function.

member.name: P:Hbm.Api.Common.DaqMeasurement.MeasurementStopUTCTime
member.summary: Stop date and time of the latest measurement in UTC format. This is the latest timestamp of all signals that take part in a measurement. Format is UTC unix time (seconds since 1.1.2000, the post decimal places are the running second)
member.remarks: Notice, that this is NOT local time, but Greenwich Mean Time (GMT)

member.name: P:Hbm.Api.Common.DaqMeasurement.MeasurementStopTime
member.summary: Stop time and date of the latest measurement.
member.remarks: This is local time and date (depends on your region and summer/winter time)!

member.name: P:Hbm.Api.Common.DaqMeasurement.MeasurementStopSystemTime
member.summary: Local stop time and date of the latest measurement, executed on this computer.

member.name: P:Hbm.Api.Common.DaqMeasurement.MeasurementTotalTime
member.summary: Total time of the latest measurement in seconds.

member.name: P:Hbm.Api.Common.DaqMeasurement.IsRunning
member.summary: Returns true, if data acquisition is currently running.

member.name: P:Hbm.Api.Common.DaqMeasurement.IgnoreResync
member.summary: Returns true if resync of a time source during a running data acquisition should be ignored. At present this is only possible for streaming devices (QuantumX family). Resync takes place when a TimeSource will be changed during a running measurement or if the time difference between two devices is rated as too high. The default value is false. The value can only be set by the DaqMeasurement.PrepareDaq() function.

member.name: P:Hbm.Api.Common.DaqMeasurement.UsedDataAcquisitionMode
member.summary: Returns the used which has been used to start the latest measurement. If the latest measurement has been started with the used data acquisition mode will be the real mode that has been chosen (, or ).

member.name: M:Hbm.Api.Common.DaqMeasurement.GroupRegisteredSignals(System.Collections.Generic.List{Hbm.Api.Common.Entities.Signals.Signal})
member.summary: Groups the registered signals, if required. If the registered signals contain DigitalCompressedSignals, there will be created one DigitalCompressedGroupSignal for each compression group (specified within the DigitalCompressedSignals). A DigitalCompressedGroupSignal contains all DigitalCompressedSignals with the same compression group number. The DigitalCompressedGroupSignal will be part of the measurement, not the DigitalCompressedSignals.
member.remarks: This method may be used in concrete device implementations if the device uses compression (one measurement value for multiple digital signals) for measuring digital signals (using ). Then its useful for implementing the device specific methods and
member.param: List of registered signals (of one device)
member.returns: Grouped list of registered signals (of one device)

member.name: M:Hbm.Api.Common.DaqMeasurement.PrepareDaq(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Prepares a continuous measurement. Participating devices are prepared in parallel.
member.param: Buffer timeout in milliseconds. Used to calculate size of internal circular buffer. At least there is a buffer of 1000 values for each signal. Normally the buffer size is (bufferTimeout/1000)*sample rate of the signal, prior added to the measurement (E.g.: Signal.SampleRate=1200Hz, bufferTimeOut=1000ms => size of internal circular buffer is 1200 entries)

Maximum number of concurrent running threads that fetch data from devices and put them into the circular buffers of the signals. At least 1 thread is necessary. Max number depends on your operation system and the number of used devices. Up to 100 threads should be no problem. E.g.: If you want to measure 20 devices, you could use one thread for each device.

Min. number of elements that will be buffered in the circualr buffers of the signals that take part in measurement. MinNumberOfBufferedValues is used if minNumberOfBufferedValues>bufferTimeout*signal.Samplerate. This is important for signals that do not have a sample rate (or sample rate = 0 Hz) which are typically all signals with SynchronMode=NonEquidistant
If true, only the first timestamp of an equidistant signal will be copied to signals measurement values during a call of
If true, only the first state value of an equidistant signal will be copied to signals measurement values during a call of
The maximum stack size, in bytes, to be used by each device data fetching thread, or 0 to use the default maximum stack size. Change this parameter e.g.when using the API within Diadem to 0.

Determines if resync of a time source during a running data acquisition should be ignored. At present this is only possible for streaming devices (QuantumX family). Set to true if data acquisition should be continued in case of a detected resync.
member.exception: Thrown, if data acquisition is already running.
Thrown, if no signals have been added to measurement.
Thrown, if maxNumberOfConcurrentDaqThreads is less than 1.

member.summary: Gets the possible data acquisition modes according to the current synchronization settings of all devices of alldevice families that take part in measurement. Normally is always possible (otherwise the devices would not deliver any measurement values at all). is only available if all devices belong to the same family and are synchronized via a synchronization cable. is possible if all devices (also of different device families) use the same .

member.name: M:Hbm.Api.Common.DaqMeasurement.StartDaq(Hbm.Api.Common.Enums.DataAcquisitionMode,System.Int32)
member.summary: Starts (synchronized) measuring of all signals that were added to the measurement.
member.param: The defines the procedure that is used to synchronize differnt devices during the start of a measurement and also the way measurement values will be provided (DaqMeasurement.FillMeasurementValues).

Maximum time in ms, that is used to start a synchronized measurement. If it is not possible to start a synchronized measurement within this time, a Hbm.API.Common.Exceptions.StartDaqFailedException will be thrown.
member.returns: Maximum difference between time stamps of the first measurement values in seconds. 0 means, that the first time stamp of each signal has the same value
member.remarks: After the measurement has been started, the start time (smallest timestamp of all signals, that take part in measurement) can be found in StartTime. If the measurement is started the function returns 0.
member.exception: Thrown, if start of data acquisition failed.
Thrown, if data acquisition is already running.
Thrown, if no signal has been added to the measurement.
Thrown, if signals have not been prepared for measurement.

member.name: M:Hbm.Api.Common.DaqMeasurement.FillMeasurementValues(System.Boolean)
member.summary: This function updates all measurement values of all signals that take part in measuring. In case of a synchronized start of data acquisition, it asserts that each signal with same sample rate (distributed to various devices) gets the same number of new measuring values. E.g. signal_A on device 1 with sample rate 20Hz gets the same number of new measurement values as signal_B on device 2 with sample rate 20 Hz! Otherwise (if StartDaq started an unsynchronized measurement, the signals get all measurement values that are accumulated since the last call of this function. This function also asserts, that there is enough allocated memory for the measurement values of each signal. So call this function periodically!
member.param: Only active in case of a synchronized start of data acquisition. If set to (default is false!) it will fill the measurement values only until the latest common timestamp over all signals not excluded from data acquisition. Signals of the same sample rate keep on getting the same number of new measurement values as described above.
member.remarks: In case of an Signal with SynchronMode set to NonEquidistant, all received measurement values will be returned! No matter how the measurement has been started (seeDataAcquisitionMode).
member.exception: Thrown, if data acquisition is not yet started.

member.name: M:Hbm.Api.Common.DaqMeasurement.StopDaq
member.summary: Stops data acquisition of all devices that take part in measuring

In case of asynchronous signals we move the read pointer to a position > start time to assert that asynchronous measurement values ALWAYS starts AFTER the given start time.

member.name: T:Hbm.Api.Common.DaqEnvironment
member.summary:
By calling DaqEnvironment.GetInstance() (DaqEnvironment is a singleton!), the system determines all pluggable DeviceFamily implementations (by analyzing the file DeviceDriver.plugins) within the directory of the executable and registers them.
After that, you are able to query registered device families and you can scan for and connect to any device, that belongs to one of the registered families.
After a device is connected, the Device object contains the full object representation of the physical device. Each Device has a list of Connector objects. Each of these Connector objects has a list of Channel objects and each Channel object has a list of Signal objects and (in case of an AnalogInChannel) a Sensor object.
You may change now any properties of Channel(e.g. Name or Sensor) or Signal(e.g. Filter or SampleRate) objects to prepare your measurement task.
After changing properties of these objects, you have to send the changes to the physical device. Depending on the changed \objects, you have to call one of the functions * Device.AssignConnector(..) - assigns also all channels, signals, sensors and zero settings under the connector, * Device.AssignChannel(..) -- assigns also all signals, the sensor and zero settings under the channel, * Device.AssignSensor(..), * Device.AssignSignal(..) or * Device.AssignZero(..). If there are unfitting or invalid settings for the specific device, you will get a list of Problem objects that describe the problems, occurred during the assign process. Unfitting settings will result in a Warning, invalid settings will \result in an Error within this list of Problem objects.
When the assignments of the settings were successful, you can go on and prepare the data acquisition by adding certain signals of chosen devices to the measurement. This is supported by the DaqMeasurement object.
Assert to call before program ends.
member.remarks: Offers access to the whole system with all devices. A user should start here to find all devices.
